Context:
The Residential Construction Management postgraduate program at George Brown College is designed to provide students with specialized skills valued in residential project management. This program offers project-based class and lab work to replicate on-site construction activities and increase practice in current industry practices and procedures.

Key features of the program include limited class sizes, which allow for increased access to lab facilities, site visits, and instructor interaction. In Semester 2, students complete a four-month field placement arranged by RESCON, providing real-life opportunities to practice skills learned in the first semester.

Graduates can expect career options as estimators, residential construction managers, residential construction project managers, site superintendents, or project coordinators within the residential sector. The program was developed in partnership with RESCON and has been successfully preparing graduates since 2013.

Required courses for Semester 1 include Quality Control & Defect Prevention (BLDG 4011), Home Design & Value Engineering (BLDG 4012), Purchasing and Bid Processes (BLDG 4013), Residential Construction Project Management (BLDG 4014), and High-Rise Residential Construction (BLDG 4015). Semester 2 consists of a four-month field placement, coded as BLDG 1080.

Program learning outcomes include the ability to assess requirements for construction industry business planning and management, formulate strategies for human resource planning and management, analyze and explain the fundamentals of building codes and legal issues including contract law, and assess safe work practices.

Context:
The text provides information about a residential construction program offered at George Brown College. Here are the key facts extracted from the text:

1. The program focuses on work practices including risk analysis and management, data production and presentation, cost estimation and control, time coordination, technology selection, team-building, technical problem analysis, and historic construction field evaluation.
2. The tuition for the first two semesters is $3,840.00 (domestic).
3. Financial assistance is available through OSAP (provided applicants meet eligibility criteria).
4. Applicants need a three-year advanced diploma in Construction Engineering Technology, Civil Engineering Technology, or Building Renovation Technology.
5. A minimum program GPA of 2.7 and department interview (resume required) are also needed for admission.
6. Domestic applicants with international transcripts require a Canadian equivalency evaluation through ICAS or WES.
7. The text includes a disclaimer that the information is subject to change without notice.
8. Space is limited in the program.

Context:
The George Brown College requires international applicants with transcripts not in English to take the college-level English assessment for admission. Applicants without English proficiency test results must undergo this assessment. For more details, please visit the English Proficiency page on the George Brown College website.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management can be contacted at 416-415-5000, ext. 6297 or by email at construction_mgmt@georgebrown.ca. For general inquiries, contact the George Brown College Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.

The college offers various related programs, including Building Information Modeling Management (BIM) (Postgraduate), Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management), and Construction Engineering Technology (T105). Campus tours can be arranged by signing up on the George Brown College website. Interested applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources to help with their application process.
